channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Libya Warns Oil Tankers Against Dealing With Militias
item.description: Prime Minister Ali Zeidan threatened to sink any foreign tankers attempting to load oil supplies from seized port terminals.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Deaths of United Nations Personnel Rise
item.description: Deadly attacks against United Nations personnel increased last year, claiming at least 58 lives, according to the United Nations Staff Union.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH C. MURPHY

item.title: Syria Reports 2 Attacks On Chemical Arms Sites
item.description: The account by Syria’s delegate to the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons came as Syria began exporting the deadliest compounds.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Crew members of a Danish commercial vessel in the Syrian port of Latakia on Jan 5.

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Chinese Official Criticizes Japanese Shrine Visit
item.description: The Chinese ambassador to the United Nations on Wednesday criticized the Japanese prime minister’s recent visit to a controversial shrine as an “affront to international justice.”
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Bird Flu Cited by Officials in Death of Canadian
item.description: In the first known fatality from the illness in North America, a person died in Alberta this month, two days after returning from China, Canada’s health minister said.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Greenpeace in New Feud With Russia Over a Ship Seized by Senegal
item.description: Just after freeing a Greenpeace crew, Russia finds one of its own ships seized, by Senegal in a poaching dispute, but Moscow blames Greenpeace for the troubles.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Adding Sex to the Chinese Dream
item.description: In a place where sex is still substantially mired in shame, some Chinese are trying to bring about a fundamental change in the way their culture views pleasure.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ma Jiajia, who owns several sex shops in Beijing, has her own take on the Chinese Dream.

item.title: The Lede: Israel’s Defense Minister Calls Settlers’ Attacks on Palestinians ‘Outright Terror’
item.description: Two cars were set on fire with Molotov cocktails and Hebrew graffiti was sprayed on the walls of a West Bank village, in apparent retaliation for an incident the day before.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Syrian Rebels Deal Qaeda-Linked Group a Reversal
item.description: Rebel fighters have ejected the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria from its headquarters in Aleppo.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Mourners carried the body of a comrade killed in the northern city of Aleppo on Wednesday during battles with the al-Qaeda-linked group Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.

item.title: U.S. to List Libyan Groups and Militant Tied to Benghazi Attack as Terrorists
item.description: The State Department was expected to apply the designation to two groups and an individual in connection with the deadly 2012 assault.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Germany Charges Former SS Member in Wartime Murders
item.description: The 88-year-old man, identified only as Werner C., was charged with 25 counts of murder in a 1944 massacre in France, while the murder case of another former SS member was dropped.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Diligence Promised in Studying Looted Art
item.description: Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, head of a task force on Nazi-looted art, says revealing a timetable would create pressure.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: India and U.S. Continue Fight Over Diplomacy
item.description: India accused the American Embassy in New Delhi of selling duty-free items to nondiplomats, which it said was a violation of the law.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Fluorescence Is Widespread in Fish, Study Finds
item.description: The findings, that at least 180 species and 16 orders of fish are biofluorescent, have implications for their evolution and behavior.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GORMAN

item.title: African Artists, Lifted by the Promises of Democracy and the Web
item.description: Technology, democratic aspirations and economic growth have created new spaces for young African artists to thrive.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel Muli, left, DJ and producer of Just a Band, with “Blinky” Bill Sellanga, the Kenyan group's lead singer.

item.title: Police Cleared in 2011 Death That Incited British Riots
item.description: A jury found that the victim had probably had a gun in the moments before an officer shot him, and called his death lawful.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Riot police confronted protesters in north London in August 2011.

item.title: The Lede: Anger in London, as Killing of Unarmed Man That Sparked Riots Is Called Lawful
item.description: Angry protests occurred outside the Royal Courts of Justice, after an inquest jury decided that police officers had acted lawfully when they shot and killed an unarmed man they suspected of carrying a gun in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Rodman Serenades Kim With a Chorus of ‘Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal’
item.description: One day after he seemed to suggest that an American citizen detained in North Korea might deserve his fate, the retired basketball star Dennis Rodman sang to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on his birthday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Dennis Rodman sings Happy Birthday to Kim Jong Un, seated above in the stands, before an exhibition basketball game in Pyongyang, North Korea on Jan. 8.

item.title: Turkish Government Shuffles Police and Seeks More Control Over Judiciary
item.description: Police chiefs in 15 cities were dismissed or reassigned, a move analysts saw as part of an effort to disrupt a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Police officers in Istanbul last month. Chiefs in 15 Turkish cities have been demoted or reassigned, the police said Wednesday.

item.title: Prison Violence Brings Scrutiny to State in Brazil
item.description: A video showing inmates gloating over decapitation victims is drawing scrutiny to the security situation in Maranhão State, run by one of Brazil’s most powerful families.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: U.S. Treasury Secretary Urges Germany to Do More on Banks and Economy
item.description: The German finance minister defends his country’s approach, even as Berlin finds itself at odds with much of Europe over a bank rescue system.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Progress Is Seen on Nuclear Safekeeping
item.description: A report on the security of deadly nuclear materials worldwide found steady improvement, but the United States slipped.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: The Lede: Sale of Tear Gas to Bahrain Blocked Over Concerns Raised by Rights Groups
item.description: South Korea’s government has reportedly decided to block the export of millions of tear gas shells to Bahrain, after months of pressure by human rights groups.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 8
item.description: Officials inspecting burnt coaches of a passenger train near Dahanu Road railway station in Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Railway and police officials inspecting burnt carriages of a passenger train near Dahanu Road railway station in Maharashtra. A fire on the overnight train killed at least nine people, a railway official said.

item.title: Leguama Journal: Ethiopian Migrants Expelled by Saudis Remain in Limbo Back Home
item.description: Many Ethiopians who were deported after seeking work in Saudi Arabia face bleak prospects at home and put a strain on the government that had benefited from their remittances.
item.dc:creator: By BENNO MUCHLER
item.media:description: Mohammed Jemal, forefront, returning home after being deportated from Saudi Arabia.
